TEXT.TITLE: James Parkinson
TEXT.PARAGRAPH:
James Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
(April 11, 1755 - December 21, 1824) was an English physician, geologist, paleontologist, and political activist.

He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
is most famous for
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
1817 work, Palsy, in which
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was the first to describe paralysis agitans, a condition that would later acquire
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
namesake known as Parkinson's Disease.

James Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was born in Shoreditch, London, England.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was the son of John Parkinson, an apothecary and surgeon practicing in Hoxton Square in London. In 1784
James Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was approved by the Corporation of London as a surgeon.

On May 21, 1783,
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
married Mary Dale, with whom
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
subsequently had six children. Soon after
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
got married,
James Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
succeeded
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
father in his practice in Hoxton Square.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
believed that any worthwhile physician should know shorthand, at which
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was adept.

In addition to
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
flourishing medical practice,
Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
had an avid interest in geology and paleontology, as well as the politics of the day.

Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was a strong advocate for the under-privileged, and an outspoken critic of the Pitt-government.
His
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
early career was marred by
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
being involved in a variety of social and revolutionary causes, and some historians think it most likely that
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was a strong proponent for the French Revolution.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
published nearly twenty political pamphlets in the post-French Revolution period, whilst Britain was in political chaos. Writing under
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
own name and
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
pseudonym "Old Hubert",
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
called for radical social reforms.

Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
called for representation of the people in the House of Commons, the institution of annual parliaments, and universal suffrage.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was a member of several secret political societies, including the London Corresponding Society for Reform of Parliamentary Representation. In 1794
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
membership in the organization led to
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
being examined under oath before the Privy Council to give evidence about a plot to assassinate King George III.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
refused to testify regarding
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
part in "The Pop-Gun Plot", until
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was certain
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
would not be forced to incriminate
himself
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself him him himself himself
. The plan was to use a poisoned dart fired from a "pop gun" to bring the king's reign to a premature conclusion. Fortunately for
Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself him him himself himself
, the whole affair was soon forgotten, and no charges were ever brought against
him
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself him him himself himself
.

Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
turned away from
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
tumultuous political career, and between 1799 and 1807
_
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
published a number of medical works, including a work on gout in 1805.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was also responsible for the earliest writings on the subject of peritonitis in English medical literature.

Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was also interested in improving the general health and well-being of the population.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
wrote several medical doctrines that exposed a similar zeal for the health and welfare of the people that was expressed by
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
political activism.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
was a crusader for legal protection for the mentally ill, as well as their doctors and families.

In 1812
Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
assisted
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
son with the first described case of appendicitis in English, and the first instance in which perforation was shown to be the cause of death.

Parkinson's
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
interest gradually turned from medicine to nature, specifically the relatively new field of geology, and paleontology.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
began collecting specimens and drawings of fossils in the latter part of the eighteenth century.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
took
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
children and friends on excursions to collect or observe fossil plants and animals.
His
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
attempts to learn more about fossil identification and interpretation were frustrated by a lack of available literature, and so
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
took the decision to improve matters by writing
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
own introduction to the study of fossils.

In 1804 the first volume of
his
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
Organic Remains of the Former World was published. Gideon Mantell praised it as "the first attempt to give a familiar and scientific account [of fossils]". A second volume was published in 1808, and a third in 1811.
Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
illustrated each volume, sometimes in color. The plates were later re-used by Gideon Mantell. In 1822
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
published the shorter "Elements of Oryctology: an Introduction to the Study of Fossil Organic Remains, especially of those found in British Strata".

Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
belonged to a school of thought, Catastrophism, that concerned itself with the belief that the Earth's geology and biosphere were shaped by recent large-scale cataclysms.
He
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
cited the Noachian deluge of Genesis as an example, and
he
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
firmly believed that creation and extinction were processes guided by the hand of God.
His
James Parkinson's Parkinson's his whose
view on Creation was that each 'day' was actually a much longer period, that lasted perhaps tens of thousands of years in length.

On November 13, 1807,
Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
and a number of other distinguished gentlemen met at the Freemasons' Tavern. The gathering included such great names as Sir Humphry Davy, Arthur Aikin, and George Bellas Greenough. This was to be the first meeting of the Geological Society of London.

Parkinson
James Parkinson James Parkinson himself Parkinson Parkinson himself _ he he himself who who himself
also contributed several papers to William Nicholsons "A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry and the Arts", and in the first, second, and fifth volumes of the "Geological Societys Transactions".
